stem: For each assessment finding, click to indicate if the finding is consistent with right-sided heart failure, left-sided heart failure, or neither.

itemContext.sbar: 07:00, S: John Smith is a 68-year-old male admitted today with complaints of increasing shortness of breath and significant lower extremity edema. He reports difficulty breathing even at rest. O: Patient is alert and oriented. Auscultation reveals crackles in bilateral lung bases. 3+ pitting edema is noted in both lower extremities. JVD is present. A: Patient is experiencing symptoms indicative of worsening heart failure. He has a history of hypertension and coronary artery disease. Current medications include lisinopril and metoprolol. R: I recommend ordering a BNP level, administering furosemide 40mg IV STAT, and obtaining a chest x-ray to evaluate for pulmonary congestion.

rationale.correct: Crackles in the lungs, S3 heart sound, and pulmonary congestion are indicative of left-sided heart failure due to fluid backing up into the lungs. Jugular venous distention and lower extremity edema are indicative of right-sided heart failure due to systemic fluid overload. Elevated BNP supports the diagnosis of heart failure.
rationale.incorrect: Incorrect selections indicate a misunderstanding of the pathophysiology of right-sided and left-sided heart failure.
clinicalPearls: Left-sided heart failure primarily affects the lungs, leading to pulmonary edema and shortness of breath.
Right-sided heart failure primarily affects the systemic circulation, leading to edema and jugular venous distention.
BNP (B-type natriuretic peptide) is released in response to ventricular stretching and is a key marker for heart failure.
rationale.questionTrap: Students may confuse the symptoms of right-sided and left-sided heart failure. Focus on the primary areas affected by each type of failure. Remember that left-sided heart failure backs up into the lungs, while right-sided heart failure backs up into the body.
rationale.mnemonic: L for Lungs (Left-sided heart failure), R for Rest of the body (Right-sided heart failure)
